questions.question_text: Which of the following operate only within the UDP protocol?

comments.content: UDP stands for User Datagram Protocol. TCP works with segments.
Ohhh i see, my bad :) Thanks!

discussion.content: Can someone please explain how B is the answer? Surely its C because segments operate at the transport layer of which UDP is found in the OSI model ?

questions.question_text: An employee reports an error when visiting a website using SSL, and a message is displayed warning of an invalid certificate. Which of the following could be occurring?

discussion.content:
Its not Evil Twin. A ET w'd be a rouge AP acting as a DHCP, or so ...
OSCP Stapling based on a google search makes more sense:
"OCSP stapling is a method for quickly and safely determining whether or not an SSL certificate is valid. It allows a web server to provide information on the validity of its own certificates rather than having to request the information from the certificate's vendor."

comments.content: Yea, my network buddy says it's MITM too. He says if it was OCSP it'll probably say revoked instead of invalid.

discussion.content: I think it’s MITM, you can be redirected to a malicious website which would give you the certificate error.
i dont like all of you.

Selected Answer: D
Man in the middle is the right answer and Evil twin is not because it uses similar character to fool the web user to thinking it was the right URL. ex. www.google.com versus www.googIe.com with a capital "i" than a regular lower case L.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct, admin needs to change.

Correct answer is MITM.
Not evil twin, because that deals with wireless AP.
Not phishing, because if so the certificate wouldn't be invalid, it would just be under the phished name.
OCSP stapling is just a method of determining whether an SSL certificate is valid. The question is asking how the certificate came to be invalid, which leaves only MITM. MITM is the only one that provides an invalid SSL certificate.
Is this because an evil twin can inject a spoofed DNS record, wich lead to an invalid certificate ? My experience is not enough to tell, it's just my best guess.

An evil twin is a fraudulent Wi-Fi access point that appears to be legitimate but is set up to eavesdrop on wireless communications. The evil twin is the wireless LAN equivalent of the phishing scam. This type of attack may be used to steal the passwords of unsuspecting users, either by monitoring their connections or by phishing, which involves setting up a fraudulent web site and luring people there.

The evil twin is the wireless LAN equivalent of the phishing scam. This type of attack may be used to steal the passwords of unsuspecting users, either by monitoring their connections or by phishing, *****which involves setting up a fraudulent web site and luring people there.****

C. Evil-Twin is correct. it is tricky question.
This is actully phising by mean of MITM (man in the middle) by mean of Evil-Twin.

Evil-Twin mean something look like same but not actual. this term refer to rouge AP. but here if you think deep. you will find. some one did MITM attack. and arp poison and divert his web traffic to some phashing website. but since that site background website has not valid certificate. so it shows error.

The following instructions describe how to mitigate SSL Man in the Middle (MitM) attacks when connecting to SSL VPN and is aimed especially for small-medium businesses who regularly have a work-from-home routine and now require near-enterprise grade security, but unfortunately do not have the resources and expertise to maintain enterprise level security systems.

Well MITM cannot be the correct answer at all because HTTP(SSL/TSL) protects against MITM attacks by encrypting all data with a secret key so my point is that MITM attacks wont be able to read or tamper with the encrypted data without the knowledge of the secret key

A man-in-the-middle attack occurs when the communication between two systems is intercepted by a third party, aka a Man-in-the-Middle. This can happen in any form of online communication, such as email, web browsing, social media,
It is definitely a MITM

It's possible that evil twin is referring to an evil twin domain. I personally haven't heard that term up until now. The term I am familiar with is typosquatting. Anyway, here is a link to possibly explain the evil twin answer:

https://blog.knowbe4.com/holiday-threat-no.-1-evil-twin-domains-with-a-trusted-ssl/tsl-certificate
Evil twin or mitm. since evil twin is a mitm attack, how do you decide which one? The question says nothing about wifi which is part of evil twin.

It's MITM.
https://resources.infosecinstitute.com/topic/invalid-ssl-certification-exploitation/
OCSP stapling is the right answer .some of the answers on this website are false

An employee reports an error when visiting a website using SSL, and a message is displayed warning of an invalid certificate. Which of the following could be occurring?

OSCP Stapling is the right answer. Evil twin only occurs in wireless. Phising is wrong as well because if you want to bait someone you shouldn't give a broken link.

OCSP protocol is a real-time check of a website's SSL certificate revocation status and “response” with the status. Thus if you got a warning of an invalid cert, that's the response from the OCSP Server. OCSP Stapling is the correct answer.
Why is phishing not a thing here?? Seems like the correct solution to me

I don't think anyone got this one right just yet. The correct answer is Phishing. The question asks "Which of the following could be occurring?", and if OCSP stapling was occuring, the employee should NOT see an error message (https://cheapsslsecurity.com/p/what-is-ocsp-stapling/).
Therefore, the only logical option is Phishing, when users access websites pretending to be somethingfuzzy.microsoft.com they usually get an invalid certificate error.
OCSP stapling is the correct answer, Evil Twin is a rouge WAP used for MITM attacks.

comments.content: Agreed. If I had to investigate potential Evil Twins for every "Invalid Certificate" message people at my office received, I'd have to hire more IT staff.

discussion.content: Evil twin is the correct answer. OSCP helps in determining SSL certificata validity and the question is not saying the user is using OSCP to do this, he is simply trying to access a website.
Can someone explain how this is evil twin? I think its the wrong answer.
Evil Twin? or OCSP stapling

The logical diagram describes the network layout, blanks etc. Change management is more about how to implement changes. You would probably put a note in change management to say you did this work, but the primary document you need to update is the logical diagram,
How is it not change management?????

comments.content: Also, keyword "refer", technicians refer to logical diagrams more than change documents when it comes to managing the network. You don't check your change logs every time you need to check your VLANs.

discussion.content: Change documents are not updated, they are created or filled like a form. A logical diagram is the one that needs to be "updated" since it may show the wrong information.
I think that the keyword here is "update" because it is the logical diagram that needs to be updated.
update=change! I don't get it:/

questions.question_text: A network technician is troubleshooting a connectivity issue and determines the cause is related to the VLAN assignment on one of the access switches in the network. After resolving the issue, the network technician decides to update the documentation to refer to the correct VLAN. Which of the following should the technician update?

A university has a lecture hall containing 100 students. Currently, the lecture hall has two 802.11ac wireless access points, which can accommodate up to 50 devices each. Several students report they are unable to connect devices to the wireless network. Which of the following is MOST likely the issue?

choices.A: One of the wireless access points is on the wrong frequency
choices.D: Distance limitations are preventing the students from connecting.
choices.C: The students are using more than one wireless device per seat.
choices.B: The students are attempting to connect 802.11g devices

discussion.content: OverCapacity- C is more likely the correct answer. there are higher chances that a student connect more than one device to the Wifi. Frequency, on the other hand, will be an issue of intermittent connection, or low signals.

I gotta agree with Shawnf. B is the BEST answer. 

A is possible... but that would impact 1/2 of the students... Q doesn't stipulate 1/2 of students, just says "several". 
C doesn't seem technical enough, but again is possible. 
D is also possible, but two WAPs in a lecture hall should be positioned to avoid distance issues, I mean just HOW BIG is this lecture hall?! 

However, B, using 802.11g devices require you know "g" uses 2.4 GHz and "ac" uses 5.0 GHz and the two are not compatible. Plus "several" students could have older devices, not half, not everyone, but several is reasonable. It makes the most sense if the Q is testing your knowledge of WiFi. 

Keep in mind, exam dumps are mostly created by test takers' "memory". So the questions are most likely not exact, nor are the answers always correct. Use them for what they are, do not memorize answers, verify and research what you don't know and you'll do great on the exam!

comments.content: Yea but 802.11ac is backwards compatible? So it should be C

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Yeah remember they are asking for a limit so overcapacity is likely what they are referring to. So this means a limit is for per student and if each of them have more than one device then acourse the limit is reached. Answer is C.

Should be C. Just think about it. Each student probably has a laptop and a phone that they're going to connect to wifi. And 802.11ac is backwards compatible with 802.11g.
"802.11ac utilizes dual band wireless technology, supporting simultaneous connections on both the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz Wi-Fi bands. 802.11ac offers backward compatibility to 802.11b/g/n and bandwidth rated up to 1300 Mbps on the 5 GHz band plus up to 450 Mbps on 2.4 GHz."
802.11ac offers backward compatibility to 802.11b/g/n and bandwidth rated up to 1300 Mbps on the 5 GHz band plus up to 450 Mbps on 2.4 GHz
i thought 802.11 ac was backwards compatable?
Theres only two devices in the room. 2 x 802.11ac. There is no 802.11g device in the room to connect to. The answer to this is 100% wrong

Question sucks but answer is correct if it is 802.11AC which only operates at 5Ghz, that has a greatly reduced range. But again it is highly possible students are connecting phones, laptops etc which would be overcapacity
Students trying to connect with 802.11g devices would be unable to connect.
I believe the answer is D. Its just a ridiculous question and a ridiculous set answers.

It could be distance. I attended Purdue University (a long time ago) and some of the lecture halls were huge (more like auditoriums) and in those lecture halls coverage with the 802.11ac range limit of 35m/115ft could conceivably prove inadequate when using only 2 APs.
I like 'B' though because if some of the students had laptops with 802.11g devices which operate only on 2.4GHz, they would not be able to communicate with 802.11ac APs which only operate on 5.0 GHz. That being said, I don't know how likely that scenario would be given that college students usually have the latest and greatest tech devices.

comments.content: The question doesn't doesn't say the hall can hold 50 students, it says each AP can accommodate 50 students and there are 2 of them.

discussion.content: Distance limitations are preventing the students from connecting. This is the right answer since the hall can hold only 50 devices against 100 students. Due to the capacity of the hall some students are outside the hall which limit the signal from a distance.

I'll let any of the 100 students sign in with his/her SID and LastName on a Captive portal just to avoid the overcapicity :). 802.11ac can go for 235 meters in distance may be the antennas are Omnidirectional and those several student whos complaining are sitting right beneath under the WAP :)

comments.content: But hey, its just for the current time their are a couple of 802.11ac WAPs and as I am the netAdmin for this campus I'll let the students to use another 2 more WAPs in the nearst future if they stopped watching pornography during classes ;)

discussion.content: Correct answer is B. 802.11g use only 2.4GHz frequency, 802.11ac use only 5GHz frequency.
I believe the answer is B. You can't connect wireless G to wireless A/C.
Many students would have a laptop and mobile phone connecting to the wifi. A full lecture hall would definitely saturate the WAPs.
I was going to say channel overlap, but that wasn't an option.
802.11ac uses only 5GHz frequency and the question doesn't say anything abt the device type the students are using. So i think the distance is the correct answer here.

comments.content: You;re talking bout channels, not frequency. Frequency needs to be the same if they are bridging the APs

discussion.content: Different frequency a good thing if both the same frequency then there be interference with each other. I think the answer is C but not certain.
This has nothing to do with distance from the scenario given. There is a possibility of a wrong configuration with the two 802.11ac WAPs. This is pointing to the frequency.
Plenum, is fire-rated cable. Has nothing to do with boosting signal. 5e has the capacity rate of 1GB over 100m distance.
Yes, the technician SHOULD upgrade the cable run to Cat5e. But in reality, it's a lot easier to simply install a repeater somewhere along that cable run. :)

Repeater install is going to require cutting the cable and crimping two RJ-45 connectors.

New Cat5e cable is just going to be some electrical tape on one end and pull on the other. (Hint: Pulling copper runs isn't hard!)
I interpreted mechanical room as potential crosstalk/interference issues and figured 5e would deal with that better.
Easiest option in this case is really repeater install

Cat 5e has more twists in the wire than Cat 5, and even though they have the same distance limitation of 100M, Cat 5e is better performing and supports higher speed (the latter isn't relevant to this Q). Better performance with tighter twists will result in less drops. Plenum is strictly a fire rating (less smoke) and has nothing to do with performance.

The clue to the answer is the Cat5 wire with a long run of 81m. So Cat5e with higher capacity is required. Mechanical room is a distraction, just to divert your mind to Plenum cable. But note that mechanical rooms are not necessarily plenum spaces which are open spaces above the ceiling or below the floor for air circulation.
Agree with Rz10, this is mainly about throughput limitation issues.
Why is the answer not plenum? what would cat 5e solve here?

questions.question_text: A WAP has been dropping off the network sporadically and reconnecting shortly thereafter. The Cat 5 wire connecting the access point is a long run of 265ft (81m) and goes through the business area and the mechanical room. Which of the following should the technician do to fix the AP connectivity issue?

choices.A: Install a repeater to boost the signal to its destination
choices.C: Upgrade the cable from Cat 5 to Cat 5e.
choices.B: Replace the UTP cable with plenum cable.
choices.D: Set the AP to half duplex to compensate for signal loss.
